definitions: central or most important point of a matter or discussion
legal basis for action in common law systems
examples: I couldn't follow everything but got the gist of the argument
The gist of her speech was about environmental conservation
The gist of the action was breach of contract
The plaintiff must establish the gist of their claim clearly

definitions: something given free as a promotion or gift
obvious sign or clue that reveals something hidden
examples: The store offered a free giveaway with every purchase
They had a book giveaway at the library fundraiser
His nervous laughter was a dead giveaway of his guilt
The muddy shoes were a giveaway that he'd been outside

definitions: someone who gives or donates something to others
examples: She was known as a generous giver to local charities
The anonymous giver donated millions to the hospital
Every giver in the community received a thank you letter
He was more of a giver than a taker in relationships

definitions: the practice or quality of being generous with donations
examples: The holiday season encourages giving to those in need
Their culture emphasizes giving as a core value
Annual giving to the university reached record levels
The spirit of giving transformed the entire community

definitions: muscular stomach organ in birds used for grinding food
examples: The chicken gizzard is considered a delicacy in some cuisines
Birds swallow stones that stay in their gizzard to help digestion
We saved the turkey gizzard to make gravy
The gizzard works like teeth for birds that can't chew

definitions: geological process of glacier formation and movement over land areas
examples: Evidence of ancient glaciation can be seen in the valley's shape
The last major glaciation ended about 10,000 years ago
Glaciation carved out many of the world's lakes and fjords
Scientists study glaciation patterns to understand climate history

definitions: large mass of ice moving slowly down a slope or valley
examples: The glacier has been retreating due to climate change
We hiked up to see the ancient glacier in the mountains
Alaska has thousands of glaciers in its national parks
The glacier carved deep valleys as it moved through

definitions: open space in a forest or woods without trees
examples: Sunlight streamed into the peaceful glade between the trees
We set up our picnic in a beautiful forest glade
Deer often graze in the glade during early morning
The glade was filled with wildflowers in springtime

definitions: armed combatant who fought for entertainment in ancient Roman arenas
examples: The gladiator raised his sword to the cheering crowd
Gladiators often fought wild animals or each other
The movie depicted the harsh life of a Roman gladiator
Some gladiators became celebrities in ancient Rome

definitions: exciting and attractive quality associated with wealth, fashion, or celebrity
examples: The glamour of Hollywood attracted aspiring actors worldwide
She added glamour to every event she attended
The fashion show was full of glamour and sophistication
Behind the glamour lay years of hard work

definitions: organ that produces and releases substances for use in the body
examples: The thyroid gland regulates metabolism in the body
Sweat glands help cool the body through perspiration
The doctor checked for swollen glands in my neck
Salivary glands produce saliva to help digest food

definitions: strong, dazzling light that is uncomfortable to look at
fierce or angry look directed at someone
examples: The glare from the snow made it hard to see
She shielded her eyes from the sun's glare
He fixed her with an icy glare across the room
The teacher's glare silenced the chattering students

definitions: Soviet policy of open discussion of political and social issues introduced in the 1980s
examples: Glasnost allowed Soviet citizens to criticize the government openly
The policy of glasnost transformed Soviet media and culture
Gorbachev introduced glasnost alongside economic reforms
Glasnost ultimately contributed to the Soviet Union's dissolution

definitions: building made mainly of glass for growing plants in controlled conditions
examples: The botanical garden's glasshouse contains tropical plants
Tomatoes grew year-round in the heated glasshouse
The Victorian glasshouse was an architectural masterpiece
Workers repaired the glasshouse roof after the storm

definitions: containers and utensils made from glass, especially for drinking or serving
examples: The restaurant invested in elegant glassware for wine service
Handle the delicate glassware carefully when washing
The antique glassware collection was worth thousands
We need new glassware for the dinner party

definitions: eye condition causing increased pressure that can damage the optic nerve and cause blindness
examples: Regular eye exams can detect glaucoma in its early stages
The doctor prescribed eye drops to manage her glaucoma
Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness worldwide
His family history put him at higher risk for glaucoma

definitions: thin coating applied to pottery, food, or other surfaces
smooth shiny surface resembling glass
examples: The potter applied a blue glaze before the final firing
Brush the pastry with egg glaze before baking
The rain left a glaze of ice on the sidewalks
The glaze on the donuts made them extra sweet

definitions: person whose job is cutting and fitting glass in windows
examples: We called a glazier to replace the broken window
The glazier carefully measured before cutting the glass
The skilled glazier restored the church's stained glass windows
My grandfather worked as a glazier for forty years

definitions: brief flash or beam of bright light, especially reflected light
examples: A gleam of sunlight caught the mirror's surface
The gleam in her eyes showed her excitement
He polished the car until every surface had a gleam
The gleam of moonlight on water guided their way

definitions: feeling of great happiness, delight, or exuberant joy
examples: The children shouted with glee when school was cancelled
She couldn't hide her glee at winning the prize
His face lit up with glee at the surprise party
They danced with glee after hearing the good news

definitions: narrow valley, especially in Scotland or Ireland
examples: The highland glen was shrouded in morning mist
They built their cottage in a secluded glen
Sheep grazed peacefully in the glen below
The glen echoed with the sound of bagpipes

definitions: smooth continuous movement without apparent effort
examples: The swan seemed to glide effortlessly across the lake
Ice skaters glide gracefully around the rink
The dance required a smooth glide across the floor
Eagles use thermal currents to glide without flapping

definitions: light aircraft without an engine that flies using air currents
examples: The glider soared silently above the mountain ridge
He earned his pilot's license flying gliders first
The glider club meets every weekend at the airfield
Modern gliders can stay aloft for hours

definitions: sport or activity of flying in gliders using air currents
examples: She took up gliding as a weekend hobby
The gliding club offers introductory lessons for beginners
Perfect weather conditions made for excellent gliding today
Gliding requires understanding of weather and aerodynamics

definitions: weak or wavering light that shines unsteadily
examples: A glimmer of candlelight showed through the window
The last glimmer of hope faded with the news
Stars provided only a glimmer in the cloudy sky
She saw a glimmer of understanding in his eyes

definitions: quick or partial view of something or someone
examples: I caught a glimpse of the celebrity leaving the restaurant
The tourists hoped for a glimpse of the rare bird
She got only a glimpse before the door closed
The documentary offered a glimpse into their daily lives

definitions: sudden malfunction or fault in a system, especially electronic
examples: A software glitch delayed the launch of the website
The computer glitch lost hours of unsaved work
They fixed the glitch in the payment processing system
A small glitch caused the screen to freeze temporarily

definitions: tiny pieces of reflective material used for decoration
bright, shimmering reflected light
examples: The children used glitter to decorate their art projects
She wore a dress covered in silver glitter
The ocean glitter in the morning sun was breathtaking
Fresh snow created a glitter across the landscape

definitions: extravagant but superficial display of glamour and showiness
examples: The award ceremony was full of glitz and glamour
Behind all the glitz was a simple small-town girl
Las Vegas is famous for its glitz and entertainment
The glitz of the fashion show impressed the audience

definitions: rounded mass or lump of a soft substance
examples: A glob of paint dripped onto the floor
She squeezed a glob of toothpaste onto her brush
The chef added a glob of butter to the pan
Globs of mud stuck to his boots after the hike

definitions: process of interaction and integration among people, companies, and governments worldwide
examples: Globalisation has connected markets across continents
Critics argue globalisation increases inequality between nations
The company expanded internationally as part of globalisation
Globalisation affects local cultures and economies

definitions: process of interaction and integration among people, companies, and governments worldwide
examples: Globalization has made international trade easier than ever
The effects of globalization reach every corner of earth
Technology accelerated the pace of globalization significantly
Globalization brings both opportunities and challenges

definitions: percussion instrument with metal bars struck by hammers, producing bell-like sounds
examples: The glockenspiel added a bright sound to the orchestra
She practiced the glockenspiel part for the school concert
The marching band featured a portable glockenspiel
Each bar of the glockenspiel produces a different pitch

definitions: partial or total darkness, especially when oppressive
feeling of depression, sadness, or pessimism
examples: The gloom of the cave made it hard to see
Storm clouds brought gloom to the afternoon sky
Economic troubles cast gloom over the entire industry
He couldn't shake the gloom that had settled over him

definitions: action of praising or honoring something excessively or undeservedly
examples: The movie was criticized for its glorification of violence
His speech was pure glorification of the company's achievements
The glorification of celebrities has reached troubling levels
History books often involve glorification of certain figures

definitions: alphabetical list of terms with definitions, typically at the end of a book
examples: Check the glossary for definitions of technical terms
The textbook's glossary helped students understand key concepts
She compiled a glossary of medical terms for patients
The glossary at the back explains all the jargon

definitions: magazine printed on shiny, high-quality paper with many photographs
examples: She subscribed to several fashion glossies
The waiting room had a stack of glossy magazines
Celebrity gossip fills the pages of most glossies
The glossy featured an exclusive interview with the star

definitions: steady light emitted by something hot or warm
feeling of warmth, satisfaction, or well-being
examples: The glow from the fireplace lit the room
The sunset cast an orange glow across the sky
She felt a glow of pride at her daughter's success
Exercise gave her a healthy glow

definitions: senior member of a college at Oxford or Cambridge universities
Spanish title of respect, similar to 'Mr.' or 'Sir'
examples: The don lectured on medieval literature at Oxford
Students met with their don for weekly tutorials
Don Quixote is a famous character in Spanish literature
They addressed him as Don Carlos out of respect

definitions: the last day of the world's existence; any catastrophic event
examples: Some people prep for doomsday with emergency supplies
The movie depicted a doomsday scenario with asteroids
Climate scientists warn of doomsday if we don't act
The doomsday clock symbolizes how close we are to disaster

definitions: change in frequency of waves due to motion of source or observer
examples: The doppler effect explains why sirens change pitch
Weather stations use doppler radar to track storms
Doctors use doppler ultrasound to check blood flow
The doppler shift helps astronomers measure star movement

definitions: member of ancient Greek people who invaded around 1100 BCE
musical mode or scale used in ancient Greek music
examples: The Dorian invasion marked the end of Mycenaean civilization
Dorian Greeks settled in the Peloponnese region
Jazz musicians often improvise using the Dorian mode
The Dorian scale creates a distinctive minor sound

definitions: simplest order of ancient Greek architecture with plain columns
ancient Greek dialect spoken by the Dorians
examples: The temple featured classic Doric columns
Doric architecture emphasizes strength and simplicity
Scholars study Doric dialect in ancient Greek texts
The Doric dialect differed significantly from Ionic Greek

definitions: white or gray bird often used as a symbol of peace
examples: A white dove was released at the peace ceremony
Doves cooed softly in the morning garden
The dove carrying an olive branch symbolizes peace
Mourning doves are common in North American backyards

definitions: fictional vampire character created by Bram Stoker; any vampire
examples: Dracula remains the most famous vampire in literature
The actor portrayed Dracula in the horror film
Children dressed as Dracula for Halloween
Dracula's castle attracts tourists to Romania

definitions: adult male duck of any species
examples: The drake's colorful plumage attracted several females
A mallard drake swam across the pond
The drake protected his mate during nesting season
Drake and duck pairs stayed together through spring

definitions: priest in ancient Celtic religion, associated with nature and magic
examples: Ancient druids conducted ceremonies at Stonehenge
The druid blessed the harvest with sacred rituals
Celtic druids served as teachers, judges, and healers
Modern druids still practice nature-based spirituality
